text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6MUte English
from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil…
speaker: Neil

text: And I'm Alice. Now, Neil, how do you get to work?
I cycle.
speaker: Neil

text: I didn't know that.
Somehow I hadn't imagined you as a cyclist.
And where's all your bike gear?
Well, I sneak in in the morning, have a shower and get changed.
That's my bike in the corner over there.
speaker: Neil

text: Oh, you've got a fold-away bike, which means it folds up,
so it's easy to carry or put away.
Do you wear Lycra, Neil?
Yes, I do… it's very comfortable.
speaker: Lycra

text: Oh. I wear Lycra as often as I can.
Lycra, by the way, is a stretchy fabric used in tight-fitting sports clothes.
Well, I'll have to see if I can catch you on your way into the building.
I'm intrigued about this sporty Neil I didn't know about.
Intrigued means to be very interested in something.
speaker: commuting

text: Well, Alice, I'm flattered.
And today's show is about commuting or traveling between your home and your work.
So how did you commute this morning, Alice?
I got the tube.
That's the subway system here in London,
also known as the Underground.
And it was a nightmare.
We stopped in a tunnel for so long that people started talking to each other.
And for those of you who aren't Londoners, that's unusual!
speaker: Neil

text: Do you ever talk to people on the train?
No. People think you're crazy if you talk to strangers.
Well, maybe now's a good time to talk about today's quiz question, Alice.
speaker: Neil

text: What question do you have for me?
All right, then. I know you like my questions, Neil.
So here we go.
What did the word commuter originally describe?
speaker: Neil

text: Was it someone who, a, traveled with other people,
b, paid a reduced fare to travel,
speaker: Alice

text: or c, traveled by train to work?
Oh, that's easy. I'm going to go for c, traveled by train to work.
Well, we'll find out later whether you're right or not.
speaker: Neil

text: Now, let's listen to a commuter in Nairobi
who takes a matato to get to work.
These are mini buses used as shared taxis in East Africa.
Can you spot a word that means being quick to notice things going on around you?
When I'm stuck in the matato,
there is a lot of strange things happening around you.
So you have to be alert in Nairobi.
speaker: INSERT

text: When you open, you leave your window open,
somebody can run away with your belongings.
You may be speaking using the phone,
somebody just snatch your phone.
You may expect that unexpected.
The word used by this commuter in Kenya is alert.
speaker: alertbelongings

text: and in these noisy crowded buses,
you need to be alert in case someone runs away with your belongings.
Belongings are the things that you own.
Right. Somebody might snatch your phone.
Snatch means to take something quickly.
Public transport in Nairobi sounds stressful!
speaker: nap

text: If I was taking the bus, I'd want to have a nap or short sleep.
Yes. Well, people have done research on commuting and stress levels,
and interestingly, women are more likely to experience stress during their journey
Why is that?
Well, they're more likely to do something,
speaker: Neil

text: which is being called trip chaining,
where they make one or more stops on the way to work,
or going home.
For example, to drop off or pick up the kids from school.
And this makes it more likely that something will go wrong with their journey.
Even if you want trip chaining, it's no fun being stuck in a traffic jam.
That's a large number of vehicles close together, moving slowly,
speaker: traffic jam

text: or being packed into a crowded train like Sardines.
Let's face it, traveling by car or by public transport can be really miserable.
Yes. Packed in like Sardines describes people standing so close together that they can't move,
like fish in a can.
So, let's hear how longer commutes can affect your health from US researcher Christine Heiner.
My study found that adults who commuted longer distances from home to work
speaker: INSERT

text: were less physically active, less physically fit,
weighed more, and had higher blood pressure than those people who had shorter commutes.
The American researcher must be talking about commuters who aren't engaged in active travel,
speaker: Neil

text: mustn't she? Because if you cycle a longer distance,
then you're being more physically active.
Hmm, I think you're right for once, Neil.
Yeah.
speaker: Neil

text: And I better start going to the gym more.
I don't like the sound of high blood pressure.
Why don't you hop on your bike, Alice, then we can both wear Lycra to work.
That's a fantastic idea, Neil. Moving on, here's the answer to today's quiz question.
I asked, what did the word commuter originally describe?
Was it someone who, A, traveled with other people,
B, paid a reduced fare to travel, or C, traveled by train to work?
And I said C, traveled by train to work, it must be right.
And you are wrong, I'm afraid.
It's B, someone who paid a reduced fare to travel.
speaker: Neil

text: The Oxford Dictionary says the word commute comes from Latin commutare,
from comm altogether plus mutare to change.
The word was used in the US in the 1840s when people paid a reduced or commuted fare to
travel by rail from the suburbs into the city.
Okay, can you tell us the words we heard today again, Alice?
Of course I can, here they are.
speaker: Neil

text: Fold away bike, Lycra, intrigued, commuting, the tube, alert, belongings, snatch,
nap, traffic jam, packed in like sardines, commuted.
Well, that's the end of today's journey with 6 Minute English.
speaker: Alice

text: Please do join us again soon. Goodbye.
Bye.
